Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc Advanced Techniques in Biomedical Research.

Overview

Overview
Researchers with highly specialised analytical and practical skills are at a premium within the research sector. Typically working in core facilities and research roles, these research technology professionals (RTP) underpin a wide range of academic and industry scientific research and can progress into significant technical leadership roles. In-depth vocational exposure to specialist techniques, equipment and infrastructure and a continuing commitment to professional development are required for a career in this area.

With an MSc in Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management students will be well qualified to enter a wide range of modern scientific employment. Researchers with highly specialised analytical and practical skills are at a premium within the research sector. Typically working in core facilities and research roles, they underpin a wide range of academic and industry scientific research and can progress into significant leadership roles. With in-depth vocational exposure to specialist techniques, equipment and infrastructure, graduates from this master’s programme will be recognised as the next generation of specialist research and technical staff. This programme will enhance students’ opportunities for PhD entry, for posts in academia or industry and this programme is therefore well suited to students committed to a career as a research scientist. In addition, skills from the programme are transferable to various other sectors, enhancing employability, graduates at Master’s level are in demand in research institutes, government departments, the Health Service, and the Environment Agency as well as opportunities in research and development within Industry.

This module is designed as the main entry to the Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facilities Management MSc programme. It is designed to allow students to develop their technical and scientific skills initially enabling them to conduct and support research in a core scientific facility. This will include all technical aspects including safety, the underlying background science and experimental limitations as well as understanding of equipment and daily operation of research core facility.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered face-to-face whilst the student is embedded within a research core facility (or in the laboratory of an experienced Teaching and Research staff member from the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences – user or manager of said research core facility).

There are 23 core facilities at present. These include various centres for OMICs (eg. Genomics, Proteomics, etc), Imaging (eg. Cell imaging, Pre-clinical imaging, etc) as well as Histology, Cytometry and many others. Instruments/techniques that students may interact with include: microscopes (confocal, spinning disk confocal, lightsheet, pre-clinical MRI, TEM, SEM, etc) including capture and analysis software, mass spectrometers, NMR spectrometers, genome sequencers, FACS and flow cytometry instruments, and more.

Supervision will be provided by Liverpool Shared Research Facilities staff member or a Teaching and Research staff member. Dual supervision will be also possible (e.g. supervisory team involving member/manager of a research facility and Teaching and Research staff member). In this case the roles of both supervisors will be discussed and agreed before the beginning of the module.
The module will be assessed by
(1) approach and technique – demonstrating progress with technical competence based equally on attendance, organisation, skills and initiative shown during term; and
(2) a live presentation encompassing the purpose, principles and limitations of the core facility technique.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop: 
1) A working knowledge and understanding of relevant risk assessments and safety procedures, techniques, their application, and core facility infrastructure
2) A deeper understanding of the principles and applications of primary techniques and relevant infrastructure in biomedical research
3) An understanding of the user base and wider context in which the facility operates.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module students will be embedded in a research core facility (or in the laboratory of an experienced researcher – user or manager of said research core facility). Supervision will be provided by members/managers of research facilities and other experienced researchers from the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences.

Here, students will acquire the necessary introductory skills to the safety, background science and daily operation of the core facility as well as gain technical experience with the core facility instrument(s).
Students will learn and work by shadowing and assisting expert scientists in their technical field. The teaching approach relies upon research-connected and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments (1) approach and technique – demonstrating progress with technical competence; and (2) a presentation encompassing the purpose, principles and limitations of the core facility technique (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Outline Syllabus
This syllabus covers the introduction to working in core research facilities in Life Sciences. Advanced training is conducted in the core research facility and will include understanding of techniques and equipment used, including their advantages, strengths and limitations. Specific skills could involve one of 23 shared research facilities including genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, etc. Students will learn how to perform hands-on work and conduct research safely within that facility including use of chemicals, biohazards, technical equipment, etc. This will incorporate experimental design, sample preparation, processing and analysis.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Students will be allocated a specific facility/technique to specialise in, at the beginning of the MSc programme.
The specific process of allocation to the research facilities (1-2 student per each facility) necessitates a decision from the admission committee of the programme before the offer of a place on the programme can be made. The admission committee will include the admission tutor and a representative from LIV-SRF. Depending on the specifics of the allocation, some candidates may be interviewed before the decision on admission is made by the committee. Students are not expected to master all facility methods, infrastructure, and practices. Instead, the allocation will determine the specific laboratory skill(s) and core facilities upon which they will be assessed.

The ethos of the learning and teaching in this module is to ensure teaching is informed and refreshed by research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching and supervision will be undertaken by researchers and technical staff in their specialist area. The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical and practical application of knowledge, integration of biomedical sciences with research (Research connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery will be similar to the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees, active learning (learning by doing) and supporting confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will be closely supervised in their use of technical equipment and in the application of their knowledge in research, planning, safety assessment, execution and support of research (Self-confidence, Active learning, Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The Departmental research environment and informal teaching sessions will assist to introduce new learning, reinforce prior learning around research and methodologies and guide the student through their learning process.

The members of LIV-SRF staff selected for these roles will have experience of teaching (including practical training) and supervision of equipment users. This experience will be largely transferable to teaching, training and supervision of MSc students. LIV-SRF staff will collaborate with the Module Organisers and the Programme Director to define attainment benchmarks for practical/technical training associated with each of the facilities. Detailed Module Handbooks will specify requirements for technical training, teaching, supervision and assessments. To ensure adherence to the Code of Practice on Assessment (CoPA), module organisers (all experienced T&R staff members) of the modules that are completely or partially based in LIV-SRF (currently BIOS771, BIOS772, BIOS773 and BIOS774) will provide training to the LIV-SRF staff before the start of relevant modules. This training will include detailed discussion of module aims, learning objectives and assessment strategies (including discussion/calibration of marking rubrics for individual assignments). To manage supervisor inconsistency in terms of assessment, all assessments will be second marked and mark reconciliation takes place if there is a 7%. difference. T&R or T&S staff will moderate all LIV-SRF – based modules.

In a typical week, students will undertake 1-2 days of facility based lab work, and a supervisory meeting with student every other week.

Description: Laboratory / Practical work. Day-to-day work in core facility.

Description: Supervision during laboratory/practical work/day-to-day work in core facility.

Supervision
Description: Regular progress meetings with project supervisor. A standardised document for recording progress will be provided to supervisors to ensure consistency in supervisory arrangements.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study including background reading, project write-up.
Attendance Recorded: No

Liverpool Curriculum framework addressed:
- Research connected teaching. Students are supervised and mentored by a research supervisor, an expert in the core research facility and its techniques.
- Active learning. Students will actively carry out independent research and background reading.
- Confidence. Students will work independently and as a part of a core facility team, allowing them to build their confidence

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is split into 2 components, each worth 50%. A bespoke rubric will be given provided for students.

Assessment 1. Approach and technique
Worth 50%; will be based upon Approach and Technique. Progress in gaining technical competence, safely working in a core facility, etc. It will adopt the format of a reflective portfolio, and includes the students' record book and is an assessment of the student's "approach and technique" and has therefore no word or size limit, or resit opportunity. Progress marked by supervisor of the core facility.
Must pass. Technical competence is required for safe working in the facilities.

Assessment 2. Presentation
Worth 50%: will be a Slideware (eg. PowerPoint) presentation -15 minute presentation (12 minute presentation and 3 minutes questions) identifying purpose, principles and limitations of the specified core facility technique. Presentations will be viewed, assessed and questioned on understanding, live in-person by supervisor and 2nd assessor. Other students on the programme will be invited to attend presentations.

Resit strategy: For Approach and Technique, re-submission of the original piece of work is not permissible. Resit opportunity will be given for the Slideware assessment using the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.
Further details on the assessments are on the table below.

Liverpool curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will compose and deliver their PowerPoint presentation.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Develop and apply advanced technical and scientific skills to independently conduct research and provide expert support within a core scientific facility
 M2 Critically evaluate the underlying principles and limitations of a core scientific facility, demonstrating the ability to assess their impact on research outcomes and operations
 M3 Critically analyse and reflect on the day-to-day practices of a core scientific facility, demonstrating the ability to apply best practices to optimise research processes and facility management
 M4 Apply in-depth knowledge and understanding of core facility technique purpose, principles, and limitations through presentation of workplace findings.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Scientific research: identify, understand and synthesise scientific principles to core facility techniques; literature searching includes primary / secondary / diverse sources; critical appraisal and application of knowledge in day-to-day work in core facility
 S2 Self-management: readiness to accept responsibility (that is, leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback / reflective learning;
 S3 Team (group) working: respecting others, co-operating, negotiating / persuading, awareness of interdependence with others.


Overview

Requirements Overview
Admission requirements are the same as the Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management MSc programme.

We will require BSc degree in Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Engineering, Computer Sciences or related disciplines (e.g. Biochemistry, Medical Engineering...). At least 2.2-degree classification (or equivalent) will be usually required. Considering vocational nature of the programme, any applicants with substantial practical/analytical experience will also be considered on a case by case basis.

The specific process of allocation to the research facilities (1-2 student per each facility) necessitates a decision from the admission committee of the programme before the offer of a place on the programme can be made. The admission committee will include the admission tutor and a representative from LIV-SRF. Depending on the specifics of the allocation, some candidates may be interviewed before the decision on admission is made by the committee.

The minimum English Language requirement for international/EU students is IELTS 6.5 with a minimum of 6.0 in each component, or equivalent.
